Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation2: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Story: I was just about to leave my apartment when I noticed my mom’s text: “Can you call us tonight? Dad’s been quiet lately.” I knew what she wanted—someone to check in, to ask if everything was okay, to be the son who notices when things aren’t right. I promised myself I’d call as soon as I got back. As I stepped into the lobby, I ran into Mrs. Kim from down the hall. She smiled, but I could sense tension. The noise complaint had everyone on edge, and I knew she expected me to be extra polite, maybe even apologize on behalf of the floor. I wanted to be the good neighbor, the one who keeps things friendly. But my mind was already with my parents, worrying about what I’d say, how I’d support them. I felt pulled in two directions—one part of me wanting to rush home and call my parents, the other knowing I should stop and chat with Mrs. Kim, smooth things over. My heart pounded as I stood there, caught between being the attentive son and the considerate neighbor, unsure which role to step into first.
